text:
SORAYA CHEMALY: Good
morning, everybody.

I'm really delighted to be
here for so many reasons.

And I really want to thank
Robin, and Lakshmi, and Liz

for inviting me and
bringing us all together.

I really actually want to thank
so many of you, all of you

in this room, for doing
the work that you do.

In my book, there are
70 pages of citations

that my publisher
wanted to put offline

because it made the
book seem too academic
and I'm not an academic.

And I put a stake in the
ground and said, no, no, no.

Those have to really
stay in the book.

So the 30 pages of
bibliography are online.

But I cite a lot of
the work that you do.

And I'm eternally grateful
that you are doing it.

Just by way of a little
bit of background,

I was a feminist
writer and activist
in college in the '80s.

And then I went
into the workforce

thinking I'll take my feminist
self, and do feminist things,

and the world will get
more and more feminist.
And that didn't happen.

And I worked in journalism and
media as a writer and an editor

and then on the business side
in market development strategy.

That then turned into
data and technology.
So I did that for 15 years.

And then in about 2010,
I decided to chuck it all

and start writing about social
justice, and inequality,

and the role of
women in the world.

And the most interesting
thing about that

was that there was such a
violent and vitriolic response.

I could be writing about the
color of children's clothes

or rape in war, and the
result was virulent.

It was rape threats, death
threats, graphic pornography.

And I started talking to other
women who were doing this work.

And they were experiencing
very similar things.

And one night we were a
group of us all together.

And we were making jokes about
the rape threats that we get.

And I didn't want to make
jokes about the rape threats
that we were getting.

And when we started
talking about it,
they didn't want to either.

And so that began a whole what
is now seven year campaign

to address freedom of expression
and the nexus of technology,

freedom of expression,
and violence--

gender-based violence, racial
violence in particular.

So the work that I
do now is writing.

But I also run a project
for the Women's Media Center

that's called The
Speech Project that
focuses on all of those issues.
And we work on policy issues.
We lobby tech companies.

We have escalation channels
when necessary to help people

who find themselves the focus of
these kinds of online attacks.

So I actually had
this book proposal

that I thought of in my head
as a book called Equal Enough,

because I kept hearing
that I was equal enough
and that I should shut up.

And I kind of had it in the
back of my head for a long time.
And then we had our election.
And anger was palpable.
It was so clear.
It was clear everywhere.

But I thought there were
two distinct angers.

One was this anger of resentment
and aggrieved entitlement,

the disgust, and
contempt, and fear

that we associate
often with anger,
and that we'd socialized.

We learned to think of
anger in those terms.

But I also saw this immense
anger of hope, and compassion,

and joy, and quest
for social justice.
And we never talk about that.

And the communities that I
belong to that were vibrant,

joyful, creative communities
came together in anger.
And it wasn't a cruel anger.
It was an empathetic anger.

So I wanted to think about
what that meant, particularly

as it pertains to those of
us who try and speak up.

There were too
many people that I

knew who were silencing
themselves out of fear.

They stopped writing
about certain topics.

They stopped speaking
in certain places.

And no one really
seemed to take that

as a degradation of
democratic norms or ideals,

because, frankly, it
was happening mainly

to women, often
to women of color.

And the traditional
approach to that

is that we're supposed
to keep ourselves safe.

But what was really happening
is that those traditional

vulnerabilities that women have
have infused our institutions.

So when we talk about fake
news or misinformation, that's

a macrocosm of
reputation damaging,

revenge porn, violent
threats online,

that we have this
public-private divide.

And so I recast the
book with this filter

of anger as a Trojan horse to
look at all of these issues

through a topic that
everybody understands,
because everybody feels anger.

But it's very clear
that we are not

allowed to express anger
virtually in any way

acceptably,
particularly as women.
So we know all the stereotypes.

There are belittling
stereotypes.

So you start off as
a spoiled princess.

How many people have seen
videos of little girls having

temper tantrums because
they're so cute?
Right.

And then you go to
being a hormonal teen

to being an angry black
woman to being a nag.

I had to laugh this morning
because I was thinking,

well, you know, people have
different practice rituals
and routines.

If you're an athlete,
you practice your sport.

And if you're a pianist,
you practice your piano.

And I laughed because
I thought, well,

what I do before a speech
is I watch morning TV.

And there was an ad
for California closets.
Actually, I was surprised.
It was a southeast Asian family.
And they were young.
And they had four or five kids.

And they had these
amazing closets.

And the husband and
wife sat at the end.
And it was going really well.

And then he looks at
his wife and he says,
I finally did something right.

And she smiled and she said,
you often do things right.

And when he said I finally did
something right, in my brain

I heard you're usually just such
a bitch, because the subtext
was she's a nag.
I'm bad at things at home.
And she gets angry at me.
And now she's smiling.

And who doesn't like
a smiling woman?
Right.

This is like getting
ready in my brain.

So I think that this
anger, this emotion,

does reside at the nexus of all
of these critical and important

issues that we think
about and deal with.

And it's not just a
matter of how we feel.

It's a matter of our
experiences and whether they
have any social traction.
So I think a lot--

I mean, there's several
books that have been written.

Brittany Cooper
wrote Eloquent Rage.

Rebecca Tracer
wrote Good and Mad.

We all know each other but
we did not write together.

We were writing three people
in three different spaces

about remarkably similar
things but in different ways.
But we all quoted Audrey Lord.

And Audrey Lord was
very influential
in all of our thinking.

And she said anger,
it's knowledge.

And I really take that
to heart because what

we're talking about in
the expression of anger
is epistemology.

And I think that's centrally
important to the kind of work

that you do and the
kind of work that I do.

The story I tell in
my book that relates

to this question of
epistemic justice
is about my great-grandmother.
And she was 14.

And she was living in what
was then called Trans-Jordan.
It was a French protectorate.
It wasn't even Jordan.

And the family fairy tale that
I was told when I was five

was that she was a beautiful
young girl walking down
the street one day.

And a handsome man on a
horse rode in, picked her up,

swept her off her feet,
rode into the desert,

and here we are, our family,
on this side of the world.

And the next time I
heard it I was 11.
And it didn't sound that great.

It didn't sound like a fairy
tale, because I'd already

been threatened with
rape, harassed every day,

I had an acute sense
of double standards,

boy-girl double standards
in my own family and school.

And so that time I
said to my family, mm,

it sounds like she was
kidnapped and serially raped.

And the guy who did
it should go to jail.

And that was my
great-grandfather.

And so two things
happened in that moment.

No one responded, which was
my first official feminist pat
on the head.

And there were two aspects
of epistemic injustice
that I see in that story.

One is that my testimony
was questioned.

And I didn't have power
or credibility for people

to consider what I was saying,
because what I was saying was,

I'm harassed, my
mother, her sisters,

every woman I see is being
harassed on the street,
and I'm scared.
I have had this rape threat.
What is going on here?
No one's talking about it.

But there was no uptake
to that testimony.

The second part though
was that by ignoring

what happened to my
great-grandmother, who
ended up catatonic by the way.

She had no ability to
function in the world
as a 56, 57-year-old woman.

But there was no social
value to her experience.
And there was no language.

There was a hermaneutic
void around her experience

and the experiences of
many women like her,

and women who experience
sexual violence, incest,
domestic violence.

It had no social
worth in our family.

And it still has poor social
worth in our societies.

And so my question
was, why don't we

have the right to
be angry about that,

and have that anger
respected and become

part of our social lives
and our political lives?

I think that what was also
interesting about this idea
that anger is knowledge.

Anger is information, is
that a lot of people think,

in corollary to that about
what Audrey Lord said

about self care, that it's a
politically revolutionary act.

And there's a deep connection
in that to another idea, which
is self-governance.

There's a thread in
Greek political history

and in our own founding
fathers' history

of the notion of
self-care and how

we define self-governance
as actually
a weapon against people.

Certain people are not
supposed to be capable
of self-governance--
black people, women.

So we have a
paternalistic approach.

When she claimed that self-care
was politically revolutionary,
that's what I think of.

I think about this idea that we
are perfectly capable of caring
for ourselves.

And this is where anger becomes
such a challenge, because we

have these sort of
aging stereotypes,

but we then also have all of the
ethnic stereotypes for women.

And these stereotypes include
angry black girls and women,
sad Asian girls--

that's a play on
the anger stereotype

because, in fact, we
divide those emotions up.

Anger is masculine and
sadness is feminine.

If you're a white
woman, you're crazy.
Right.

And if you're Hispanic,
maybe you're hot.

And maybe you're compared to
a consumable food substance.

All of those are belittling
but they're also infantilizing.

And that act of infantilizing us
in our anger is paternalistic.

It is denying us the
right to self-governance.

And so I was
really, really taken

with these ideas of
courage and conviction,

because, as a writer,
language is super important.

And I would argue
that the work you do

is even more important
from that perspective,

because I look to your
work to fuel my work.

I explicitly set out in 2010 to
take the amazing academic work

that I've been
reading for decades

and try and make it more
popularly consumable, give it

narrative framing, give
it political resonance
in the moment.

So if you look at a
lot of my articles,

there's more red hyperlink
than actually no red hyperlink.

And that was just my way of
trying to literally write

an 800 word article
that had 50 links in it

so that people could go find
this work that they might not
come across otherwise.

But the words courage and
conviction are also gendered.

Most people when they
think of the word

bravery think of
men and masculinity.
And they think of protection.

And the idea of
protection doesn't

extend to women, for
example, as mothers.
They're protecting us all day.

They're protecting us
from food toxicity,
from environmental toxicity.

In my house I'm
the techie person

from predatory online
harassers, whatever.
But we don't call it protection.

And so even these two words,
courage and conviction,
can be problematic.

And I'm so happy because
I know you know that.

I don't need to cite your
research to explain that.
But the thing is that in anger--

and this begins for girls
when they're young--

there is this quality
of self-defense.

And, in fact, we're
all socialized to put

the needs of others first, to
be communal in our orientation,

to subsume our own needs, and
to use our nice voices, to smile

more, to be considerate,
to not interrupt

as much, and, in
fact, in the end,

to act in ways that are
subservient or subalternate,
or submissive.

And in doing that,
indignity becomes
imminent in our femininity.

And so in the past seven months,
since my book was launched,

I would say that the most
common response I get

is, I didn't even
know I was angry,

because we become so detached
from even understanding
the emotion in ourselves.

We learn to calibrate
ourselves so carefully

to the environments we're
in and to the people where

with so that we are
pleasing and nice
and make people comfortable.

And it takes a lot
of time to come to.

And when we do,
it's often the case
that people get angry back.

And they don't get angry back
because of what we're saying.

They get angry back
because we're angry.

In intimate relationships and
interpersonal relationships,

particularly if
they're heterosexual,

women who get angry are
perceived as selfish,

as difficult, as
self-centered no matter
how legitimate their grievances.

And so when you scale that up
into institutions, as we know,

that turns into a more
explicit display of power.

It's hard, I think,
for people to talk

about power in their
interpersonal relationships,

a little easier
in the workplace.

But we know that power
accrues to men as leaders

when they display anger,
and that, in fact, women

are penalized for
displaying the same.

And so when I did
write the book,

it was a direct response
to the treatment
of political candidates.

That idea that anger might
be a good way to do this

really struck me during
the debates and in the fact

that Bernie Sanders
and Donald Trump could
leverage public populist rage.

They could physically
leverage it.

They could stand at
a podium and thump it

and look unhinged with
their hair and their hands
and their pallor.

And there was Hillary
Clinton literally bound

in her flak jacket under
her jacket and on the stage

and didn't have the
physical freedom, her hair--
everything about her.

And actually, that idea of
taking up space with movement

is also related to anger
and childhood socialization.

We have all of these norms
with little children.

Boys can go twice as far
away from their parents
when they're learning to toddle.

They learn to be
physically expansive.

And the interesting
thing to me, one

of the more interesting
bits of research

that I've found
in doing this, was

the relationship between your
physical appearance and mean

and the production
of testosterone.

Because one of the
responses I always

get when I talk about
how women should or can

or do express themselves,
whether there's aggression,

or anger, or just assertiveness
is well, of course,

boys and men are more
of all of those things

because they have so much
testosterone, when, in fact,

the behavior and
the testosterone

have a mutually
productive relationship.

They are not one-- that's
not unidirectional.

This combination of
things, as a writer and I

believe as an academic,
becomes really complicated

around the notion
of subjectivity.

Anger is subjective in
that it centers the self.
I need this to happen.
I feel this is wrong.
I have a problem.

And in stating this, as calmly
or as irrationally as I might,

I'm saying that you have to pay
attention to what I'm saying

and that indeed
I'm going to hold

you accountable as a
person, as an institution,

as a political system,
and women are not supposed
to hold people accountable.

They're not supposed to
demand accountability.

And if you remember
the Larry Nassar trial,

it was one of the first
times in my memory

that I can think of a judge
allowing women in the hundreds
to jointly make statements.

Usually, rape
victims are isolated.

They're not allowed
to testify in unison
or in the same procedure.

And this judge allowed them
unlimited time to do this.

And then she made a
closing statement.

There was really no different
from the closing statements
that any judge might make.

And liberal media
men criticized her

for being subjective
and not objective

and for inserting her own
perspective, which, in fact, is
what judging implies.

But there is a conflict
in some people's minds,

because of the linguistics
between woman and judging.

And we have the same conflict
with woman and anger.

And the duskier the lady,
the bigger the conflict,

because it can't possibly
be reasonable that she
has this demands to make.

So in media, it's often
the case that those of us

who do this work or
have this perspective
or do these research--

do this kind of research are
considered inherently not
objective.

And that then means we
enter the stupid realm
of false equivalences.

So if you have a really
knowledgeable scholar,

whether it's in the
issue of gender and race,

or climate change
or creationism,

and intelligent
design, they're then

pitted in media with someone
who knows nothing, has not

done the work, has
not done the research,

and is given equal
legitimacy, because

of this kind of understanding
or lack of understanding

of some of the issues
that we're talking about.

And so it's difficult to be
in the position of having

your courage and
convictions be so unwelcome,

because they are material
challenges to the status quo,

to power, and I would
argue ultimately

to people's personal sense
of status and identity.

In the work that I do,
which is increasingly

focused on the more and more
granular, younger, and younger,

younger, because I'm
being winnowed down

to giving up on
adults, it's clear

that the performance of
certain types of masculinity

trumps the safety and
well-being and rights
of children and women.

And this isn't to
say that is equally

available as a political
tool to all men,
because it's very clearly not.

President Obama could
not display anger,
because he was a black man.

So you have all these
stereotypes about women,

but we know that
in this country,

black male anger is
associated with criminality.

Now, that's a different
kind of power,

because it's a
threatening power,

but it's not the power
that many white men have,

which is that their anger
is by default considered

a civic virtue and that
it has political residence

and it hearkens back
to a long tradition.

All of these issues to me we're
accessible through stories

about anger, my stories,
and other people's stories,

and stories about what
happens when we express

our convictions, and
what the pushback is,

and what we do
about that pushback
and how we manage that.

I am not a therapist, but
at the end of the book

I have sort of 10
broad outlines of how

to rethink anger so that it
can become a useful tool.

I was particularly
concerned for immediately

the people I know
doing this work,
because they're all exhausted.

They're tired, and
they're exhausted.

And a lot of the exhaustion
comes from stress,

but a lot of the stress
comes from not being
able to even say, I'm angry.

So the name Rage Becomes Her is
a play on several things, one

of it being that without the
acknowledgment of this emotion,

which many people struggle
with this, particularly girls

and women, without
acknowledgment
it becomes material in the body.

It contributes to a
whole array of illnesses,
physical and mental.

And one of my objectives
was to say stop--

we have to stop
making ourselves sick.
We have these convictions.

We are courageous,
but it shouldn't
consumers in this way.

And if you have a framework and
a language for understanding,

if you have the research that
explains what this looks like,

then you can be more creative,
productive, healthy, joyful,

compassionate, and have
more political efficacy.

I'm not really big on
personal narratives
of change and victory.

And I think that's
important, but for me,

anger and self-care are
manifested in political action
and in the work--
the work that you choose to do.

And because the issues
are so granular,

the solutions have
to be granular too.

And they have to be
available to everyone,

because these
problems can seem so

big and overwhelming
that people detach.
They don't want to do the work.

They don't know
how to do the work.

And they throw up
their hands in despair.

But in fact, there
is a lot that people

can do in the small everyday
interactions of life,

which was what I
was hoping to be
able to convey with the book.

So I do want to close so
we have time for questions.

I want to say thank
you all again so much.

Your work is very
much appreciated
in my part of the world.
